ÊàëÁöÑÂ§©Á©∫ÈáåÊ≤°ÊúâÂ§™Èò≥ÔºåÊÄªÊòØÈªëÂ§úÔºå‰ΩÜÂπ∂‰∏çÊöóÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫Êúâ‰∏úË•ø‰ª£Êõø‰∫ÜÂ§™Èò≥„ÄÇËôΩÁÑ∂Ê≤°ÊúâÂ§™Èò≥ÈÇ£‰πàÊòé‰∫ÆÔºå‰ΩÜÂØπÊàëÊù•ËØ¥Â∑≤ÁªèË∂≥Â§ü„ÄÇÂá≠ÂÄüÁùÄËøô‰ªΩÂÖâÔºåÊàë‰æøËÉΩÊääÈªëÂ§úÂΩìÊàêÁôΩÂ§©„ÄÇExtremely touching, the ÁµÜ between Yukiho and Ryouji. „Åù„ÅÆ‰∫∫„ÇíÁµ∂ÂØæ„Å´ÂÆà„Çã„Å®Ë®Ä„ÅÜÊ∞óÊåÅ„Å° is quite common to see in Japanese novels, TV series, movies and so on. What I like the most about it is, everything is implied - ÁïôÁôΩ„Å®Ë®Ä„ÅÜ„ÇÇ„ÅÆ„Åß„Åô. There is no direct expression of emotions, feelings or sensations. We are left to imagine and savor what the protagonists are experiencing in those dramatic moments. Throughout the novel there was no direct description of what has exactly happened to and between Yukiho and Ryouji, but that is indeed unnecessary :)In addition I really like the narrative techniques of Keigo Higashino. The novel is divided into chapters and smaller sections, and usually there's a dominant, quasi-protagonist-ish character, from whose perspective a certain series of events are seen, usually spanning a few sections. It produces a fragmented view of the big picture, and the reader is expected to cobble up all small fragments together. It makes the reading experience a bit more active, rather than totally passive.I am indeed deeply touched by this book.

I loved Higashino's¬† Salvation of a Saint and The Devotion of Suspect X.¬†Malice and A Midsummer's Equation¬†were enjoyable, but not nearly as remarkable. This, though: this was something else, written by someone else. Much like the book's cover--terribly apropos--it suffered from vague character outlines, wildly specific details of inanities, and a general lack of attention to the (normal) scenic clarity that elevates Higashino above the ordinary.¬†This story begins shortly after the third anniversary of Saori Namiki's disappearance when she was nineteen. A decrepit house has burned down in Tokyo and her remains were identified in the rubble. Chief Inspector Kusanagi and his team are assigned the case because of a curious connection they have to the chief suspect. Most unusually, they had a disastrous encounter with him almost two decades earlier when a young child went missing. Higashino almost always (at least, that I recall) has truly terrible people as murder victims, which builds in reader sympathy for the killer. With that knowledge, I had a feeling I knew where the story was going, but it wasn't until Part Two, at page 87, that we finally reached the main course.Oh, how I was looking forward to this story, but the pace! The pacing was terrible. We spend pages with the grieving family as the police revisit the missing-persons case (we also get a plethora of details about said house). It's terribly slow, and it turns out to be somewhat of a useless preface; the book isn't about Saori's death as much as it's about her killer's eventual death, and that's a very odd thing indeed. Once we reach Part Two, Saori and the family almost disappear from the pages.Part Two transforms into obsessive Sherlockian details, with timing, placement and clues being examined in minute detail. It's extremely fussy, and while I tried to follow along at first, after the first double-back, I gave up. The locked room is an insanely complicated (but naturally, diabolically clever) murder route. This is the overly-fussy detailed section of the story, where physics and volume come into heavy discussion. I kid you not. Higashino must have been reading some Andy Weir. At one point, I was so disinterested in finishing that I peeked at other reviews who promised a twist ending. This does indeed happen, but the contrast to the beginning of the book is startling.¬†Higashino's particular specialty seems to be turning the traditional questions of where-when-why-how and looking at them from unusual angles. This one feels a little like Salvation of a Saint in that much of it is a locked-room sort of mystery. I was also getting a strong feel of Murder on the Orient Express vibes as I read (for those worried about spoilers, I wrote this before finishing). Perhaps also giving me a Christie vibe was the cast list at the front of the book. Regardless, nothing here really stands up to the emotional or intellectual puzzle of Salvation and Suspect X.The most enjoyable sections were scenes at the Namiki family restuarant/bar where it all began. I got the feel for the cultural of the local establishment, the way people would drop in for a meal on the way home or for a weekly night out with friends. Yet much like watching people come and go from the corner booth, we never get too close to their lives, only their expressions and thoughts of the moment. And seriously, who passes up the chance to go into loving detail about foods and drinks? And allows one of their detectives to order a virgin Moscow Mule? Oh, the literary horror.Speaking of literary horror, I can't help but notice that my two favorites of his were translated by Alexander O. Smith, while this one, and unfortunately an upcoming release, are translated by Giles Murray. (There's a online interview of the two that's an interesting read). Is it Higashino aging? Translator skill? Or both? I can't help but think how much I enjoyed Robert Parker's Spencer books at the beginning, but found them to be lightweight copies by the end of his career. Perhaps there is a similar phenomenon happening.The other aspect I enjoyed were the snippets into Japanese life. In this case, the criminal system was highlighted. Apparently the police--and the public--place a great deal of value on confessions. Also interesting was the small bit of detail about the local parade. Hiashino doesn't include much however; most of it I found on my own. Japan is known for matsuri, community celebrations, often religious or seasonally connected, but occasionally just reflecting the local people's tastes. It doesn't seem like The Silent Parade is based on a particular matsuri, although interestingly, there is one that became a 'silent' dance festival after there were too many noise complaints.Well, rather than read the next, I really should give my two favorites a re-read. After all, I've only read them once.A moment of silence seems appropriate, does it not?

3.5 stars, rounded downThis may be the 9th in the Detective Galileo series, but it‚Äôs the first I‚Äôve read. But I had no trouble jumping into the series. This can easily be read as a standalone. I can‚Äôt remember reading another mystery that takes place in Japan. I found it interesting to see the differences in our justice and policing systems, which play a pertinent role in the plot. Higashino also does a great job of giving us a great sense of Japanese culture. A talented young girl goes missing and her remains are discovered 3 years later in a burned out house. Despite lots of circumstantial evidence pointing to one man, he is not prosecuted. A few months later, on the day of a large parade, he is found dead. ‚ÄúDetective Galileo‚Äù is actually Professor Yukawa, a professor of physics. He consults with the Tokyo detectives on the case. While his ideas are a key part of the book, he‚Äôs not a major character. The book had a Sherlock Holmes feel to it. Yukawa is able to fathom the clues that the detectives don‚Äôt quite see or understand. The book is the opposite of fast paced. It introduces so many characters they are listed at the front of the book. While I was curious to see how the mystery would be solved and who was behind the death, it was a little slow for my taste. And parts of how the crime took place were easy to figure out. Others were totally out of the blue. And just when you think you see how it all played out, a wild twist is thrown in. This is not a character rich book. I never felt I got a true feel for the personalities behind the main characters. While it was a decent read, I doubt I will follow through with reading the prior books in the series. My thanks to Netgalley and Macmillan Publishers for an advance copy of this book.

I am a huge fan of the author ever since I read The Devotion of Suspect X way back in 2018. I was really impressed with the writing, the detective work, the characters and the murder mysteries in this series!Detective Galileo aka Manabu Yukawa is not your traditional detective and you will know why when you read this book. And yes to nerds, the mystery solving involves Physics and basic scientific explanations you know! But you will understand all the explanations given. Apt for everyone (the casual as well as the avid mystery book lovers).‚ú®Highlights:‚òëÔ∏èeasily accessible writing/language ‚òëÔ∏èmemorable characters ‚òëÔ∏èmurder mystery which is more like a psychological thriller read with a good closure‚òëÔ∏èmyriad memorable characters ‚òëÔ∏èshort chapters which will make you fly through the book‚òëÔ∏èfast paced with unique plotThe story is about solving the mystery of disappearance of a beautiful young girl at the verge of getting famous as a singer whose skeletal remains get discovered three years later. And even then the police and the detectives are having a hard time to solve this mystery with all the obvious clues available. Also the suspect gets murdered. So who is behind all these murders? ‚òëÔ∏èYou don‚Äôt need to read the first three books in the series. Each book handles different murder mystery cases and can be read as a stand-alone in no particular order.Thank you @writersmelon @hachette_india for sending me the book.

Oh the joy of a new Keigo Higashino novel, and a Detective Galileo book at that! They are such little marvels, so fussy and intricate, and yet I find the experience of reading them the book equivalent of a mug of hot tea on a chilly day. This is not quite as down-into-the-details fussy as SALVATION OF A SAINT but I think it's just behind it. It takes a while to get to the meat of the mystery, and even after we do we move between a pretty wide cast of characters. We have more than a hunch that several of them are involved in the crime we just don't know exactly how. Motive is never the question, only how was it done. This is quite an unusual one, maybe just a bit beyond total believability, but I appreciate a new and extensively-considered murder scenario that I never have to actually worry about in real life, and this fit the bill. Perfectly paced, as always, with a new little twist waiting every time you think it's just about all figured out. It's nice to have Detective Galileo back, he is a Sherlock-esque guy except for how everyone likes him so much. Keep translating the Higashino's please, I know there are more we haven't gotten yet and I will not be satisfied until I have read every single one.

Well structured murder mystery with an amazing number of switchbacks (lol you think you've just worked it all out? Sucker.). Author is a genius of the garden path and leading readers there-up. Hugely enjoyable.

Probably somewhere between a 4 and 4.5 stars - it's not quite topped Salvation of a Saint as my favourite in the series, but it's pretty close! Definitely on par with Devotion of Suspect X for me.This has become my all time favourite mystery series - I really love our main trio and their dynamic, and Higashino's ability to make you think you know what's going on and then throw you in for a loop at the end is truly unmatched. Silent Parade is as much of a page turner as the previous books in the series, and I loved every minute of this.What I really loved about this story in particular are the interconnected cases - we have a case from Kusanagi's past that ended in the culprit getting away with his crime because of the flawed justice system, a similar case in the slightly more recent past seemingly linked to this same killer, and then finally the murder of this suspect in the present day. I can see some people finding this a bit convoluted, but I personally really enjoyed this setup and seeing the links between the cases!One thing I will say is that the further on in the series we get, the more obvious it is that the English translations are skipping books in the series. There are callbacks and character/relationship developments that are implied, but that I have no context for. I can only assume they took place in the books that weren't translated. If the publisher is reading this, please, I beg, give us translations of all the books in this series üò≠If you're a fan of crime procedurals and murder mysteries, I cannot recommend this series enough!Thank you to St Martin's Press for providing me with an e-ARC in exchange for an honest review!

An accident, a perfect crime, or just revenge?‚ÄúSilent Parade‚Äù is part of the Detective Galileo Series, but many significant things unfold before readers actually meet him. A man was charged with murder. He was guilty, plain, and simple, and yet he insisted he did not do it. Without a confession and without hard evidence, the police had no choice but to release him. Some time later, he dies during an annual parade. Surely this death is not just a coincidence. The obvious suspects, the family of the murder victim, all have ironclad alibis; the Investigation hits a brick wall. It requires the skills of Professor Manabu Yukawa, better known as Detective Galileo, professor of physics and unofficial consultant to the Tokyo Metropolitan Police Department. He unravels impossible crimes and is called upon when a case is problematic, and that certainly describes this case perfectly. While his theories may sometimes seem preposterous on the surface, in the end they are intuitive and correct.People are the focus of this story, and Higashino constructs a narrative with extensive background information about all of them, their past and present activities as well as their involvement in previous cases; after all, one of these people is a murderer. Every reaction, thought, and deed is meticulously documented, both the important and the mundane. Even the geography is described in detail. Detective Galileo‚Äôs investigation is focused, methodical, and comprehensive; the smallest details are investigated. What people believe to be the truth and what the actual truth is are not necessarily the same thing; perceiving the difference is the key to solving the crime. ‚ÄúSilent Parade‚Äù starts with what seems to be a perfect crime. The every detail of the murder is intricately planned and executed. The perpetrator thought of everything except Detective Galileo. Like assembling a jigsaw puzzle, one after another, he slotted the pieces into place, and they all fit perfectly. I received a review copy of ‚ÄúSilent Parade‚Äù from Keigo Higashino, Minotaur Books, and Macmillan Publishing. For those not familiar with the series, a handy reference of the characters and their jobs is included. Every book in the series is compelling and surprising. Detective Galileo always looks at things from a different point of view.
If you haven't read anything by Higashino before, probably you would give it a 3.5 stars to 3.75. But yif you would, it's a 2.75.

I love Detective Galileo books. These are very unique with twisted plots. This one was no exception A cold hearted sociopathic killer who evades the justice system, two murders 20 years apart, lives destroyed ... And finally prof Yukawa uniting everything into a plausible story. One star less because the plot felt very contrived when I came to know the final solution .

Many thanks to NetGalley and St. Martin's Press/Minotaur Books for an advance copy of the book in exchange for an honest review.Though last to be translated into English, Silent Parade was my first Detective Galileo novel of the series. It's a very well-written murder mystery full of twists until the very end. It does have some similarities with Murder on the Orient Express by Agatha Christie, and Hercule Poirot's name is mentioned twice even, but the aforementioned twists take the story to a different path from Christie's book. I liked how the story was told from the different points of view belonging to several people related to the murder, not only from the detectives' eyes. It was definitely a page-turner, and the different narrations spiced things up, working with the misleading tactics well enough that the twists could come later as a shock to their readers.All in all, I enjoyed the book very much and planning to delve into the previous Detective Galileo novels soon.

This one was ok. I enjoyed the Suspect X one more. It's long, and there were parts of this that became redundant and dragged. The parade day itself was interesting and I liked many of the diner placed scenes and conversations. Yet, and this a big yet- the crux of the motive? And the stated and actual lengths of time that crimes can be prosecuted (Statute of Limitations) in Japan was, to me, shocking. For very serious crimes like moving or manipulation of a body- only 3 years?There are only so many times you can praise and describe the singing talents of a dead potential young star. And who/ how that potential never being realized or taken for profits either. Would that be intrinsic before the success occurring at all? Or be so life path situation changing? (Not just for her but for others?) Regardless, even with the very Japanese cultural onus for success or children's choices for career or whatever path toward the traditional "best"? I didn't get this as a real fit for all that here in urban Japan. It seems much more Chinese dragon parent or Western civ. country familial must do ambitions for taking over the business or profession.Also the manner for one of the demise/ death scenes in process and aftermath ending? Way, way harder to do than portrayed here for that last departure. But it was SO Japanese in how easy/often the confession seems to arise. Almost spontaneously with any provable guilt evidence.This is much more a character study than a who-dun-it, IMHO. Not just for 2 or 3 either- more like 6 characters in depth. That's worthy of some time. Yes. But Detective Galileo comes in here way down the line of copy and I think overall- it's just not a length or pull for my most liked novels in this genre. Pacing is barely a 3 star, more towards a 2.It was sad too. I'd like to visit that place (family diner/restaurant) as a "regular" and get the fried oysters though.

Weird how this series mostly having the same formula but I am still in awe on ways of Higashino created his premise. ùôéùôûùô°ùôöùô£ùô© ùôãùôñùôßùôñùôôùôö has that great details that I love, the characterization gets me enraptured, the execution and development were riveting and enthrallingly suspense, the crime itself though nothing fancy, but utterly cunning and making me go baffled at times. You could basically get the rough idea about the crime from the blurb and easily guess on the killer (ahh... should I go with plural here?) or probably on the motives too. From an eatery outing to a local autumn festival (the backdrop is so admirable!), a plan of revenge is set to go (5 stars to their friendship and trust) when the music starts as the first team go marching for the parade. Yall, is it possible that Keigo is able to DO IT AGAIN!It was emotional, the whys and hows kept me up and it had left me with this deep emotional turmoil that is not only heart-wrenching but the facts are just so painful.
 "What you believe to be the truth and the actual truth are not necessarily the same thing. Until you know the difference, you can't make the choice that will decide your fate.
This book is my fourth book of Keigo's and I swear this man writes just the best things. He has sealed to be one of the best authors in my heart. The story, the way it was narrated and how everything fell into place felt just so very surreal and unfair.  Personal Ratings : 4.5üåü With every Keigo's books, I will not give anything much, as like his previous works, its best to go in blind. Just dive in the world that is written by Keigo and you'll be hooked. What I can say is that this book gave me similar emotions as The Devotion of Suspect X did. It was heartbreaking and everything that happened was just so geniusly written. Keigo has a way that can make you feel everything and anything. The way he writes the lives of the people and how everyone is somehow interconnected with one another. The way he integrates the ordinary lives of people and the sceneries in Japan with characters that never fails to make you love and pity them.Yukawa and Kusanagi in here shines so much in this book. I loved their friendship and their banters and Yukawa's involvement in here is just, immense. I liked how Keigo integrates Yukawa's role in the series. His deduction skills and everything in here, his dynamics with Utsumi was one that made me so hooked with this series and his writing. Their dynamics and conversations were the highlight of this book. Whilst the case part did not WOW-ed me as much as his previous works, it was one that is so very technical which was what I loved about Keigo's books. One thing I would like to say with this book is how real and raw the portrayal of the justice system. Its cruel and unfair and it shows how technicalities of the law has cause so much pain to ordinary people that drives them to do something that is morally wrong. It was heartbreaking and my heart goes out to everyone who has been in the same predicament. Keigo had done a wonderful job in portraying the outcomes of such technicalities that is not only tedious but also does not do justice to the victims at hand. I highly suggest everyone to read Keigo's works, at least once in your lives. Its a good start if you want to venture into Japanese Murder Mystery and paired with character-centric stories, it will definitely make you hooked. This book is nothing less of a masterpiece and I will highly recommend it to everyone!Thank you to Pansing Distributions (@definitelybooks) for generously providing me a review copy of the book.Disclaimers: All my reviews are my thoughts of the book and according to my personal preferences. Even though I had received a review copy, it does not affect my review and honest thoughts for the book.
3.5 stars actually, not his best, not the best in the series, but still interesting enough.

While this is Book #9 in the Detective Galileo series, it is only the fourth to be translated into English. A young singing prodigy disappears, and her body is found in a house fire about three years later. The house belonged to the mother of a man accused of a prior murder, who was released because he remained silent throughout questioning and his trial and the jury would not convict based on the circumstantial evidence. He is thought to be the culprit again, but is released by the police. On the day of the local parade, he found dead in his room, and the most obvious suspects have solid alibis. A quality police procedural, with a clever plot with many suspects with a motive to kill the victim.
The very fact that I oscillated from 2 stars to 5 stars for this book speaks about the creative writing. Tough to review this one without giving away spoilers.

I am convinced that Keigo Higashino can do no wrong... every single one of his books slap. I genuinely only read the mystery genre for his books and although this book isn't even one of his top 3 for me, I can comfortably give it a 9.1/10 and it is much better executed than majority of the mystery genre. Anyway if any one has more mystery reccs like Higashino please recommend to me :)

[UPDATE 01/05/2022][ARC from NetGalley in exchange for an honest review] - English and Vietnamese review3.75/5(English)It's still a mystery crime book as usual but Keigo always left me a mixed-feeling in the end.This book has a huge plot and the writing style is quite different to the Keigo's style we normally see. The reason that I say this book is different is because the story doesn't follow the normal rule we usually see in Keigo's books. The way that he links two old cases is odd enough but this plot is even not in any ascending nor descending order. In Silent Parade, the good news is Galileo is portrayed even better than in Salvation of a Saint. Keigo did a good job in expressing the characters and he never fails to impress me in that part.In this book , the mystery crime factor dominates the society factor and the plot twist is quite surprising. This book has a strong start but a weak end and the author left some of the events' outcome for the reader to figure out themselves but this decision of Keigo is not as satisfying as in Journey Under the Midnight Sun.In the end, Tomoya Takagaki is the most miserable one.----------------(Vietnamese)C≈©ng ch·ªâ l√† m·ªôt quy·ªÉn trinh th√°m th√¥i nh∆∞ng sao l·∫ßn n√†o t√°c gi·∫£ c≈©ng ƒë·ªÉ l·∫°i cho ng∆∞·ªùi ƒë·ªçc m·ªôt c·∫£m gi√°c b√¢ng khu√¢ng kh√≥ t·∫£. 3.5 starsIt was enjoyable, however, it doesn't hold a candle to other Keigo Higashino books.

Silent Parade is the latest North American release for award winning Japanese author Keigo Higashino. This is the fourth entry in his Detective Galileo Series - but you'll have no problem jumping into the story. 'Detective Galileo' is actually not a part of any police force. Instead, he is a physics professor with an incredibly quick mind. His deductive powers could be compared to Poirot's. His good friend, DCI Kusanagi with the Homicide Division of the Tokyo police has drawn on Professor Yukawa's skill set before. Two young girls have been murdered decades apart. What they have in common is the suspect - and the investigator. DCI Kusangi worked the historical case and is determined to solve this latest.There are many players in Silent Parade and I was appreciative of the list of characters at the beginning of the book. I liked the enigmatic style of Professor Yukawa and the dogged determination of DCI Kusanagi. The family of the missing girl were very well drawn. The supporting cast is detailed enough to make each of them a suspect.Higashino's plotting is detailed, intricate and downright devious. Just when I thought had things figured out, he upended all my suppositions and the investigation headed in a different direction. This happened more than once - and I loved it! Higasino is a clever, clever writer.I enjoyed learning more about everyday life, social mores and celebrations in and of the Japanese culture, as well as the legal system. Giles Murray was the translator and did a fantastic job. The prose never felt wooden or awkward at all. I enjoyed the pacing of the book as well - a slow burner that lets you become immersed in the tale.I would absolutely read the next book from Higashino.

In my opinion, the writer relied on Agatha Christie‚Äôs Murder on the Orient Express book and wrote a version of it placed in a Japanese setting. That is why I am also expressing my criticism in comparison to this story. To be honest, Japanese society and culture have always been sympathetic to me, I feel like I should have been born there more, my thinking and ideas are close to that. This is why the slow, systematic and yet effective thinking that manifests itself in the actions of both the perpetrators and Professor Yukawa does. Because in this story, it is not the investigators who are the positive actors, but the victims who become criminals. I felt the role of the police was secondary and unethical, I didn‚Äôt understand why the good was being persecuted with all their might, and they were reassured that the evil, the killer, could not be imprisoned. Therefore, the victims must unite so that the wicked will receive a worthy punishment. Here, too, the dilemma arises as to whether we can expect the state, the judicial system, to deliver justice. That would be his job. But our experience is that if we want to deliver justice, we have to take care of it ourselves.

A girl vanishes. Fruitless investigations and three years pass away. Then a fire unearths her body. It seems that she had been murdered. Subsequent investigation draws one man into the crosshairs.Interestingly, nineteen years ago he had been in a similar position with respect to the death of another girl! At that time Kusanagi was just an enterprising officer. He had bitterly felt the taste of failure when the suspect couldn't be prosecuted. Now, as Chief Inspector, would he like to take charge of this investigation?Police pursues the case with utmost vigour and enthusiasm. But things seem to be heading towards the same direction, even after the passage of two decades.Then something unexpected happens."If you take a life do you know what you'll give?Odds are, you won't like what it is."Everytime I come to the end of a novel penned by Higashino, I hope for something. It can be exhileration felt by a Police Officer at the end of a successful prosecution. It can be world-weary cynicism of a hardboiled PI. It can even be that satisfactory thrust of vengeance, when the perpetrator finally gets what had been coming for him/her.I never get it! Instead I end up with a canvas of bitter-sweet feelings.Higashino's novels are like those grand panels, where every character, every motive, every action and reaction are presented in hard, unforgiving colours. You can see them. But judging them would eventually be like judging your own aesthetics, senses, life‚Äî as you look at it.You would realise that the crime, the MURDER, didn't happen like you, the characters, the Police had envisaged. Instead, suddenly, you would realise how the murderer might have felt.And yes, you would suddenly understand the meaning of those catchy words penned by Chris Cornell and David Arnold.This is a classic. You need to read it slowly, meditatively, with cups of tea at hand. Because, as a very important character observes, "Tea signifies remembrance and also pure love." This novel, despite everything, is a commemoration of pure love.Highly recommended.

5 stars. I absolutely love Higashino's books, particularly this series, so was really excited to find out only a few days prior to release day that there was going to be a new one translated this year. Read within a day of its release, and loved it like I did all his other books. I‚Äôm reading this series out of order, since the books are being translated out of the original order of the Japanese novels, but that wasn‚Äôt felt at all as they essentially read as standalones.Detective Yukawa is the most thoughtful of my favourite investigation protagonists (there are others that I like, but they are all more gung-ho / rash), and I love how I can almost see him thinking when I read one of these books. Everything that he does has a reason ‚Äì there is no time to give the mind a rest because there are clues being dropped all over the place ‚Äì and as always the books are so meticulously planned.I really liked the setting of this one ‚Äì true to its title, the plot of the murder mystery was intricately woven into descriptions of a large parade that was coming to town. I had sort of guessed that (view spoiler)[ the cases of the two murdered girls would have something to do with each other. Higashino doesn‚Äôt waste even a sentence for things that the reader doesn‚Äôt need to know, not to mention entire chapters dedicated to what happened three years ago. That being said, just as I thought that for once I had a sniff of a chance of figuring out a Higashino plot, he hits me with the intricately planned murder to levels of detail that I had not even come close to considering (though I did wonder what all the fuss re: water and oolong tea was all about!)  (hide spoiler)] and once again I was left starstruck at the end.And now, I go back into what feels like my default state of waiting for his next book to be translated ‚Äì and when that happens I‚Äôll get it and devour it in a day :D

Clever idea--to have a murder conspiracy within a murder conspiracy. Yet it takes so long to work things out. The story is told, retold, and then told and retold again. And again. Each time adding a bit more to the facts and the truth, both of which are often at odds with each other. The result is that the clever idea becomes overwhelmed by a mechanical narration in which the inevitable grimly plays out. Yes, there is a surprise. But then it's not a surprise either. Like with many Higashino mysteries, you can see it coming before it reveals itself. The joy in his books is supposed to be watching the events play out. That could have happened with Silent Parade but for the necessity of constantly replaying events. The story couldn't have worked without the replay. But the replay also ends up making things plod along. Still, Professor Yukawa, aka Professor Galileo, is at the top of his game as usual. It's just that the game lasts sooo long.

Enjoyable.As is often the case with Higashino, and many J-mystery writers, the mystery as presented is not the real mystery. It is the path that leads us to even knowing what we are looking for that forms the suspense of these tales.This one, is a rather good one overall. There were times when the truth poked out, but KH has a great ability to make you forget that you knew as he spins you around a bit.Besides that, this book also works as a nice intro to some of the oddities of J-police procedure, as compared to the usual business of western countries. So, a bit of ‚Äúculture‚Äù one might say.I always look forward to KH‚Äôs nearly once a year release, and will continue to do so, as of the dozen or so out in English now, possibly only one was bad and one more not so good, leaving a great average.Recommended
Probably my least fav of the author. RTC

This is not the first entry in the Detective Galileo series, but it is my introduction to it, so there are recurring characters and relationships that were already established but were new to me. That wasn‚Äôt a problem, since the writing and dialogues are clear enough to understand where the characters are coming from. I loved the twists and turns of the story. When remains are found in a house linked to a suspect that evaded arrest in the past, CI Kusanagi from the Tokyo Police tries to catch the guy this time. The guy is so slippery that it seems like he‚Äôs going to get away with it once more when he dies in mysterious circumstances during a famous parade. It‚Äôs impossible for one person to have done it, but could more than one be involved? The dead girl was loved by everyone and her family has many friends. Some quotes from an Agatha Christie classic made me think that I knew where it was going, but I was wrong. Manabu Yukawa, also known as Detective Galileo, comes up with possible theories. The story put me in an unusual position because I liked the cops, but I was rooting against them. If the victim‚Äôs family murdered the bad guy, I wanted them to get away with it. All the characters, the detectives and the suspects, were so relatable and likable, it was hard to root for one side against the other. But the final solution was really unexpected and rounds out the perfect whodunit. I chose to read this book and all opinions in this review are my own and completely unbiased. Thank you, NetGalley/#St. Martin's Press, Minotaur Books!

The Story:
 Two murder cases with twenty years apart and the only suspect dies unexpectedly during the annual Kikuno Story Parade. Not only his death was suspicious, all the possible suspects with the best motives have rock solid alibis. Detective Chief Inspector Kusanagi of the Homicide Division of the Tokyo Police once again turns to his physicist friend Professor Yukawa also known as Detective Galileo to help solve this baffling case.
My thoughts:
 Ooh-wee! Higashino has done it again with this latest installment of Detective Galileo series! I've been waiting forever for this fourth book and it did not disappoint! Totally worth the wait! So after reading this author's previous three books, I thought I was smart enough to solve this case but nope. It was masterfully crafted with a LOT of twists! I gasped, my jaw dropped and was completely blown away by how well-plotted this book was! I absolutely loved the logical thinking and deduction process used by Professor Yukawa in solving the case. It was like Sherlock Holmes and Hercule Poirot plus a lot more layers of mysteries and twists! This was a slow-burn mystery with a lot of characters - both from the past and current case - are introduced into the story. But thank goodness for the list of characters in the beginning which helped a lot! I think this book works fine as a standalone but you may miss out on the backstory of Yukawa and Kusanagi's friendship. The first book - Devotion of Suspect X - was incredible, so you may want to start right from the beginning anyway! In a nutshell, READ THIS BOOK! Pub. Date: Dec 14th, 2021***Thank you St. Martin's Press, Minotaur Books and NetGalley for this gifted review copy. All opinions expressed are my own.***

At the risk of being called a philistine, I found that keeping a running list of all the characters featured in Keigo Higashino‚Äôs SILENT PARADE did the trick for me. There are so many Japanese names here that it was difficult to tell who was who. My list helped me to separate the good guys from the bad guys and the characters from the past vs. those from the present, making the reading experience so much more worthwhile for me.The book‚Äôs central theme revolves around a cold case that may not have been a coincidence. Local restaurant owners Yutaro and Machiko Namiki seemingly had it all. That is, until the day their beautiful and gifted teenage daughter, Saori, failed to come home from school one day. They did everything they could to find her, a true community effort based on her popularity, but she has not been seen alive since.Three years later, Yutaro and Machiko are contacted by a man from the Shizuoka Prefectural Police. The skeletal remains of Saori have been positively identified. The police are confident that a certain suspect is the guilty party, but unfortunately they only have turned up circumstantial evidence against him and cannot proceed with an arrest.What they have been able to trace is a potential pattern of missing young women. It turns out that 23 years earlier, 12-year-old Yuna Motohashi also vanished suddenly without any clues regarding her fate. A man named Kanichi Hasunuma was put on trial but was found innocent due to lack of evidence. It is this same individual, much older but just as deadly and untouchable, who the police are eyeing for Saori‚Äôs abduction and murder.It is at this point that the great Detective Galileo is called upon. His methods have drawn literary comparison to those of Sherlock Holmes; his unique style and level of success in solving seemingly impossible crimes are needed now more than ever. But don‚Äôt count on an unchallenging ride for Galileo. Higashino has more than a few tricky plot twists up his sleeve that will completely change the circumstances with which Galileo is forced to work. The ending of SILENT PARADE is extremely clever and unpredictable.Reviewed by Ray Palen

Actual rating: 4.5/5Keigo Higashino is undoubtedly one of the best when it comes to thrillers. This is yet another mind boggling thriller from Detective Galileo series. In India, many times criminals go scot free using the loopholes in our legal system. Seems like Japan is no different. A criminal has been let off the hook twice inspite of all the circumstantial evidence against him for murder. And now this criminal himself is found murdered‚Ä¶This is not only a story about criminals making a mockery of the legal system but also the psychological impact this has on the bereaved families.Yet another masterpiece from the master storyteller.

A fast-paced story. And keep me from the edges the whole time, if I have enough time, I guess I can actually finished this in one sitting. The characters are so well developed, you can really get to know each and everyone of them throughout the story. The only down side for me is that it ends at a really sudden place. The ending is a great surprise though! Now I am looking forward for the Japanese drama as people had been saying that it is even better than the book itself!

You absolutely should read this book if you have nor read yet. The boook is one of the representative works of Keigo Higashino, who is the one of the most popular authors of mystery novels. While it is a mystery novel, you are also able to read this book as a pure literature which tells you about the truth of family and love. I thought the book very unique in this sense, and since the book does not include any of difficult languages or cruel scene, it is absolutely readble for every readers. If you are looking a book which you are able to find the both aspects of entertainment and pure literature, this would be best book to read!!

‡∏Ü‡∏≤‡∏ï‡∏Å‡∏£‡∏£‡∏°‡∏Ñ‡∏∑‡∏ô‡∏ù‡∏ô‡∏î‡∏≤‡∏ß‡∏ï‡∏Å. A crime story about 2 brothers and a sister whose, when they slipped out of the house in the middle of the night to see meteor shower, their parents have been murdered in their own restaurant. When grown-up, the 3 brothers accidentally founded the suspect from that murder they swore to take revenge. With their own little private investigation, what they've found is a shock discovery not only for them but for readers also. Well crafted from the beginning to the end. A classic.
One of the best books I've read of K.Higashino. 80% Mystery, 20% RomanceÔºéSweet revenge.
Perfectly plotted storyline. A great combination of love and revenge.

Sungguh di luar dugaan @bukugpu @fiksigpu menerjemahkan & menerbitkan Black Showman dan Pembunuhan di Kota Tak Bernama lebih dahulu ketimbang Wandering Blades. Apalagi, GPU hanya mengunggah trailer buku 10 hari sebelum periode pra-pesan dibuka. Sebagai bucinnya Higashino-sama, tentu saja aku tidak boleh melewatkan ini.Ceritanya menarik. Higashino-sama menggunakan latar waktu ketika kita masih dalam kondisi pandemi. Semua harus berjaga jarak & mengenakan masker. Perjalanan wisata harus dibatalkan & mobilitas warga jadi semakin terbatas. Dari situlah dia menyusun plot cerita serta penyelidikan dengan menarik.Black Showman dan Pembunuhan di Kota Tak Bernama menghadirkan 2 tokoh utama. Seorang paman yg eksentrik dan seorang anak perempuan yg polos (hingga aku sebal huh!). Mereka berdua ingin segera mengungkap siapa pembunuh seorang guru SMP tapi merasa tidak terlalu memercayai kinerja polisi (uhuk familiar).Selain dinamika emosi antartokoh yg dibangun dengan baik, Higashino-sama juga menyelipkan banyak trivia terkait budaya populer di Jepang serta hal yg berhubungan dengan novel detektif. Tapi tenang saja, kalau kamu kurang mengenalinya silakan cek catatan kaki. Tim penerjemah & penyunting sudah menghadirkannya agar kita tetap bisa menikmati cerita.Secara keseluruhan, aku sangat menikmatinya. Novel ini membuatku ingin segera menyelesaikannya dalam sehari. Tebal 516 halaman bukan menjadi persoalan asal segera tahu siapa dalang & apa motif tindakan kejahatan itu. Tentu saja, build-up emotion yg dilakukan oleh penulis telah disampaikan dengan baik oleh Milka Ivana sebagai penerjemah naskah.Ohya, rating Black Showman adalah 17+ untuk beberapa paragraf terkait minuman beralkohol serta kondisi korban ketika ditemukan.Astaga, memang tidak sia-sia aku menjadi bucinnya Keigo Higashino ü•∞

As a fan of Keigo Higashino I enjoyed reading this book so much. I'm fascinated to read his books because of his creativity and his love to details. The first book I've read from him was "The Devotion of Suspect X" which was mind-blowing and he kept exceeding my expectations through his original view on many different themes. As you can imagine, I mostly end up giving 4-5 stars to Higashino books because I love them so much. This was a different take of a "detective" which I liked. It was more light-hearted but still had great characters, good flow of story and interesting setting (a small village during Covid-19). I especially liked the chemistry between the main characters, Mayo and Takeshi. I hope to read more about Takeshi and his case-solving-stories in future! Btw, it also would be interesting to see a combined story between American and Japanese people. (Since Takeshi was working a long time in the USA).I also adore the Korean edition I have. The book design is beautiful (minimal design in red, black and gold) and it includes a very interesting booklet fitting to the story. Furthermore, it was a small dedication to Korean readers which I thought was sweet.

page turner banget sih bukunya, lancar banget aku bacanya, emang keigo higashino ga diragukan gaya menulisnya ! dari awal aku udah berusaha nebak siapa yg ngebunuh tapi pas sampe ke ending gaada yg bener WKWKWK semua dibikin suspicious gitu, ada aja yg bikin kita curiga dan kayak ‚Äúhah ngapain sih begini‚Äù tapi pas tau endingnya beneran ada benang merahnya semua ! poin plus : TAKESHI NYENTRIK BGT AKU SUKA NGAHAHAHA NYEBELIN TP KARISMATIK GITU

Bertemu Higashino lagi dalam naskhah 'standalone' tentang kes pembunuhan seorang guru di sebuah kota kecil di Jepun. Berlatar sekitar pandemik Corona, Kamio Takeshi, bekas ahli silap mata terkenal pulang setelah mendapat khabar kematian abangnya yang disyaki dibunuh. Penceritaannya dari perspektif Mayo, anak saudara Takeshi yang sama membantu Takeshi dalam usaha mengumpul info dan petunjuk kepada kes kematian ayahnya, Eiichi. Perkembangan cerita agak perlahan dan terlalu deskriptif tapi aku suka dengan suasana bandarnya yang suram dan terpencil juga karakter-karakternya yang menggugah rasa ingin tahu. Motif dan pelakunya mudah diramal di pertengahan cerita namun aku tertarik nak tahu bagaimana Takeshi akan rungkaikan kes tanpa sebarang lompong dan buat pelaku tersepit dan mengaku. Rumit dan intens, tak sangka kerana sebuah reuni sekolah segala kisah silam, rahsia-rahsia persahabatan dan hal keluarga malah kehidupan Eiichi sendiri boleh buat dia hilang nyawa. Suka dengan watak Takeshi (teringat watak Kaito Kid dalam Conan) yang tegar menyiasat dan pintar menghasut lawan bicara terutama dengan pasukan penyiasat polis, Maeda dan Kakitani. Karakter yang keras kepala, licik dan pandai berdalih-- cara penyiasatannya penuh rahsia dan ilmu silap mata, agak jengkel juga tapi sangat saspen dan setiap babak sentiasa ada twist yang buat aku ingin lebih tahu. Agak menarik bila ada satu bab dengan perspektif si pembunuh di penghujung cerita jadi boleh tahu kisah dari sudut yang lain juga.Walau masih dalam acuan dan tema penyiasatan yang sama dengan buku-buku detektif Higashino yang lain, ideanya masih menarik bagi aku barangkali kerana ada kelainan pada karakter dan latar utama kali ini. Terjemahan juga agak bagus dan tahniah juga untuk penerbit yang pantas siapkan kerja terjemahan dan penerbitan naskhah ini. 5 bintang!ps: berharap ini naskhah bersiri jadi boleh jumpa Kamio Takeshi lagi :'))
Review bisa ditonton di video February wrap up yang ini https://youtu.be/nSQe-EBMJTA?t=190

Beres bacanya, mau sedikit ngeluarin unek unek setelah menyelesaikannya. Kalo boleh dibilang, tingkat antusiasme pembaca pas nyambut info kalo gpu bakal nerbitin karya terbarunya Keigo Higashino terbilang tinggi yah. Apalagi ini novel di Jepang sana juga masih hangat terbit karena memang mengangkat tema pandemi sekarang. Dari semua novel keigo-sensei yg udh pernah diterjemahin ke bahasa Indonesia, ini novelnya yg paling tebal dan alurnya juga terasa lambat. Kalau kalian berharap ada plot twist atau dapet sesuatu yg mengejutkan di akhir cerita, kalian gabakal nemuin itu di buku kali ini.Di 1/5 bagian isi ceritanya baru sadar kayaknya tipe bercerita yg dipake keigo-sensei di buku ini sama seperti cerita detektif klasik pada umumnya, mencari tahu pelakunya atau yg biasa dikenal whodunit. Kukira bakal kyk Malice yg pake tipe bercerita whydunit ataupun kyk Salvation of a Saint yg pake Howdunit. But, isokaay di judul Black Showman ini kembali menggunakan whodunit karena mungkin yg ingin ditonjolkan di cerita ini sisi 'eksentrik' si tokoh utama. Karakter Takeshi sebagai paman Mako begitu mengingatkanku sama karakter Kaito Kid di cerita detektif conan. Sekilas jg sbnrnya udh keliatan sih ya dari cover bukunyaüòÇ. Tapi bener2 karakternya yg nyentrik dan unik ini bakalan loveable sepanjang cerita sih.Di 2/5 isi cerita mulai kerasa dan sadar kalo alurnya mulai lambat.Mungkin hal ini yg bikin si bukunya tebel. Penggambaran detail mengenai keadaan pandemi COVID-19 begitu terasa dekat dan relate bagi sebagian besar orang. Selepas baca jadi kangen sama temen-temen sekolah, karena kalo dilihat garis besar ceritanya mengisahkan bagaimana hubungan pertemanan Mako dan kawan kawannya semasa SMP berlanjut setelah mereka dewasa. Untuk narasinya mengalir dan enak dibaca, ga bosenin. Kerja bagus penulis dan penerjemahnya. Overall aku puas sama karya baru Keigo-sensei yg satu ini, tidak sabar menunggu terbitan judul lainnya yg katanya bakal hadir di 2022 ini

Seperti biasa, novel detektif karya Keigo Higashino selalu berhasil bikin aku ga mau berhenti baca sampai halaman terakhir.. (walaupun pas pertama kali ngeliat tebalnya emang bikin jiper, sih.. üòÖ)Hal yg paling menarik buatku dari novel ini yaitu setting waktunya saat pandemi COVID-19. Penulisnya menggambarkan kehidupan kota kecil yg jadi terpuruk akibat pandemi. Wisata dilarang, ekonomi jadi lesu. Persis dgn yg kita hadapi sekarang.Ceritanya memang agak lambat di awal, karena jumlah tokoh yg diperkenalkan cukup banyak dan narasi world-buildingnya. Alur bertambah cepat sejak mayat Pak Guru Kamio ditemukan. Rasanya gak ada satupun hal di novel ini yg dibiarkan "sia-sia". Semua tokoh punya peran penting (bahkan yg cuma muncul sesekali), latar belakang mereka diceritakan mendetail. Tokoh yg paling berkesan tentunya si Paman Takeshi üòÅüëç orangnya teliti banget, suer.. aku bertekuk lutut deh sama kemampuan analitiknya üëèüëè Nih kalo beliau jadi polisi, kayaknya kasus apapun bakal terbongkar sama doi ü§£ü§£ü§£Dari segi plot twist, menurutku ga terlalu "wow".. yang bikin aku kagum justru motif kasusnya. Ternyata gak sesederhana yg aku kira. Ada masalah perselingkuhan, ekonomi, persahabatan, (dan banyak lagi yang terlibat). Keren banget sih, penulisnya bisa bikin cerita seapik itu tanpa bikin pembacanya jadi kebingungan ataupun jadi plot hole. Bravoo üëèüëèKekurangan novel ini, menurutku cuma satu. Ada beberapa pengulangan narasi yang sebenarnya kurang perlu (karena udh dijelasin di bab-bab awal). Lumayan tuh, kalau dihilangkan bisa mangkas beberapa halaman üòÇSecara keseluruhan, novel ini memang worth-it. Plotnya seru dan ditulis dengan baik, aku kasih 4,5/5‚≠ê buat rating finalnya.

Takato Yoichi si Dalang dari Neraka, musuh bebuyutan Kindaichi, adalah seorang pesulap. Makanya, waktu baca sinopsis Black Showman ini, saya langsung otomatis keinget dia dong haha. Kirain kan bakal mirip-mirip gitu. Ternyata di buku ini, peran sang pesulap adalah detektifnya, bukan villain-nya.Anyway, ada dialog Takato di File 24, Pembunuhan Boneka Rusia yang saya ingat betul:"Esensi sulap ada pada akting melebihi trik itu sendiri."Kata-kata tersebut tampaknya memang benar adanya, sebab si pesulap dalam buku Black Showman ini juga menganut filosofi yang sama. Kamio Takeshi adalah manusia manipulatif (atau seperti bahasa Mayo, "penipu") yang jago banget akting, terutama untuk mengorek informasi. Kemampuan akting itu jelas diasahnya selama dia tampil sebagai pesulap di Amerika.Saya suka kasus di buku ini. Cara penyelidikannya, juga bagaimana plot berjalan sembari mengupas misterinya pelan-pelan, asyik banget dinikmati. Misteri besarnya memang "siapa yang membunuh Kamio-sensei", tapi ada misteri-misteri lain juga yang menyangkut orang-orang lain yang terlibat dalam kasus ini. Dan karena penasaran, saya menyelesaikan buku ini nonstop selama lebih-kurang empat atau lima jam. Bener-bener nggak bisa berhenti.Nuansa ceritanya sendiri nggak menegangkan, meskipun bukan berarti nggak seru. Banyak komedi juga di dalamnya, gegara hubungan ngegemesin Takeshi dan Mayo selaku paman dan keponakan. Si Mayo ini, karena nggak biasa dengan urusan kedetektifan, awalnya terkesan naif dan bingung... tapi lama-lama akhirnya dia terbiasa dengan ritme penyelidikan, sekaligus terbiasa dengan metode-metode eksentrik sang Paman. Banter mereka lucu dan nyenengin dibaca--bagaimana Mayo selalu mengeluhkan keanehan pamannya sementara pamannya selalu menganggap Mayo telmi (makanya dia berulang kali mengeluarkan frasa "untuk ukuran seorang Mayo"). Tapi jelas mereka berdua tim yang kompak dan efektif, dan "saling menyayangi" sebagai paman dan keponakan. Haha.Highlight lainnya dari novel ini adalah Covid-19, tentu saja. Kayaknya ini termasuk buku fiksi pertama yang mengintegrasikan kondisi Covid di dalamnya ya? Setelah ini dari seluruh penjuru dunia pastilah akan terbit banyak novel lain yang di latar waktunya menyertakan kondisi pandemi global, tapi buku ini termasuk pelopornya. Dari buku ini, kita bakal memperoleh gambaran bagaimana kondisi Covid memengaruhi kehidupan sehari-hari di Jepang--yang tentu saja, sebetulnya nggak seberbeda itu dengan kondisi kita di Indonesia. Di Jepang sana juga ada WFH, rapat daring pakai Zoom aplikasi video conference, streaming pemakaman online, jaga jarak, pakai masker, sterilisasi, disinfektan, hand sanitizer, pembatasan ke luar kota, pembatasan berkerumun, dan sebagainya--istilah-istilah yang familier selama dua tahun lebih kita berada di kondisi pandemi. Jujur saya kagum banget karena Higashino-sensei bisa dengan cepat menjadikan kondisi pandemi sebagai latar novel pembunuhan yang benar-benar terkini. Saya sendiri sejak pandemi, setiap mau menulis cerita realistic fiction, selalu mengambil latar tahun paling mentok 2019, demi menghindari kondisi pandemi. xDKasus dalam buku ini sebetulnya nggak terlalu rumit, tapi berlapis karena melibatkan cukup banyak orang dan mengupas drama-drama seputar mereka juga. Mungkin secara general agak mirip The Newcomer - Pembunuhan di Nihonbashi--kasus yang kelihatannya pelik tapi sebetulnya simpel, tunggal, triknya nggak macem-macem, dan motifnya bukan sesuatu yang "wah" banget, bahkan cenderung sepele. Bedanya, kalau di Newcomer sudut pandangnya banyak dan orang-orang yang diceritakan itu nggak terlibat langsung dengan kasusnya. Sementara di Black Showman ini, hampir sepenuhnya diceritakan hanya menggunakan sudut pandang Mayo dan drama-drama manusianya menyangkut langsung ke para tersangka kasus.Saya suka bagian revelation kasusnya. Kayak cerita detektif beneran, mengumpulkan semua tersangka dalam satu ruangan, memberikan gimik jebakan, barulah mengungkapkan analisis satu per satu dan akhirnya pelakunya nggak punya jalan buat mengelak lebih jauh. Tapiii, kebenaran kasusnya sendiri agak nyebelin. Kenapa? (view spoiler)[Satu, karena sebenarnya pembunuhan itu nggak disengaja. Si pelaku nggak berniat membunuh, cuma membakar, tapi kepergok, ya udah deh akhirnya bunuh. Menurut saya itu nggak banget.Dua, karena bikin saya jadi punya trust issues sama mangaka! #woy Motif pembunuhannya nyebelin banget! Dan sebagai pecinta animanga, saya sulit dan nggak tega ngebayangin hal seperti ini terjadi pada suatu judul animanga populer. Terlalu heartbreaking. Selain itu... dalam latar belakang kasus ini, mau nggak mau terlalu banyak pemikiran akan "it shouldn't be this way". Maksudnya, kalau sejak awal si Kugimiya nyantumin nama Tsukumi atau setidaknya ngasih kredit "based on story idea by Tsukumi Naoya", misalnya, hal seperti ini nggak perlu terjadi. Dia tetap bisa menikmati kesuksesannya. Animanga Gen Laby juga nggak perlu ternoda. Asli hati saya sakit banget ngebayangin popularitas Gen Laby langsung jatuh gegara mangaka-nya begitu.Soalnya... meskipun ide cerita itu dicuri dari Tsukumi, kan tetep aja eksekusi manga-nya--yang sampe berhasil 10 tahun serialisasi--adalah hasil kerja keras Kugimiya! Toh Tsukumi nggak bikin panel per panel? Dia cuma nulisin ide besarnya aja. Pengembangan ceritanya, yang sampai diwujudkan ke dalam gambar, dialog, dsb kan dari Kugimiya sendiri. Kalau misal perlu bagi royalti ke ibu Tsukumi, ya udah tinggal bagi aja. Beres, kan?Sepertinya Kugimiya setakut dan semerasa bersalah itu karena dulunya dia anak terpinggirkan yang selalu diremehkan, lalu ketika berhasil mendapatkan segalanya (kesuksesan, ketenaran, dsb), dia jadi takut banget kehilangannya. Makanya dia sampe pengin melenyapkan bukti itu, dan pada akhirnya, melenyapkan Kamio-sensei juga. (hide spoiler)]Yah, intinya sih, saya nggak suka kebenaran di balik kasus. Sementara untuk lain-lainnya, menurut saya buku ini oke banget. Page turner, nyenengin, bikin penasaran sekaligus ketawa-ketawa. Epilog-nya juga bagus meski dibiarkan menjadi open ending. Barangkali ada yang bakal bilang kalau buku ini kebanyakan tell, tapi bagi saya nggak masalah. Novel Jepang biasa begitu, dan selama masih bisa dinikmati, kenapa harus komplain? Apalagi ini novel misteri. Kadang fakta-faktanya memang harus diceritakan saja. Overall saya menikmati sekali membaca buku ini. Kalau waktu bisa diputar ulang, saya pengin baca ulang buku ini berkali-kali dengan reset otak setiap mau baca--jadi seolah-olah pembacaan itu adalah kali pertama, tanpa pengetahuan tentang apa yang terjadi. Saya juga berharap karakter Kamio Takeshi akan muncul lagi di novel-novel Higashino-sensei selanjutnya. Dia karakter yang supermenarik, memorable, dan masih banyak misteri yang melingkupinya. I'd love to see him again!

Aku sangat menikmati buku ini karena sangat menggugah keinginan membaca sampai habis dan terasa personal. Pembaca gak akan mendapatkan twist yang terlalu wah dan gimana2. Twist nya simple aja dan gak mencengangkan. Tapi yg menarik adalah cara pengungkapan twist itu. Jadi saranku, nikmati saja perjalananmu dengan pengungkapan kasus iniüíú‚ú®Buku ini juga mengobati kerinduanku pada buku Keajaiban Toko Kelontong NamiyaüíúNarasi dalam buku ini mirip dengan narasi di Namiya. entah aku merasakannya, buku ini judul ke-3 dari Keigo-sensei yg kubaca. Dan aku merasakan suasana berbeda pada narasi Namiya dan Kesetiaan Mr.X namun Black Showman ini lebih mirip dengan Namiya.Untuk plotnya menarik dan fresh karna setting nya pun saat pandemi Covid ini yang *uhuk* kita tau blm kunjung selesai üòåRelevansi setting membuat aku bisa memahami situasinya lebih baik. Aku tidak keberatan dengan tebalnya buku ini, dibilang datar pun tidak kok. Malah Black Showman menjadi karakter yang menarik karna sangat cerdik dalam menganalisis sesuatu yg sama sekali tidak ia ketahui, juga karna analisisnya yg memakai pendekatan psikologis dari para tersangka itulah yg mengantarkan pada satu fakta. Yang mana tidak bisa dilakukan oleh polisi profesional üëè‚ö†Ô∏èMight contain spoiler‚ö†Ô∏èMotif pelakunya juga gabisa dibilang flop, karena itu menguatkan karakter Eiichi-sensei sebagai sastrawan dan kecintaannya pada literatur dengan ttp memastikan orisinalitas suatu karya.Untuk tokoh Takeshi pun juga menarikkk. Keigo-sensei dapat mengeksekusi Takeshi menjadi tokoh yang sulit dipercaya karena 'slengean' namun ternyata punya bakat yg sangat besar üòÇ

Kamio Mayo sedang mempersiapkan pernikahannya saat dia mendapatkan kabar ayahnya meninggal dunia. Mayo bergegas kembali ke kampung halamannya dan meninggalkan Tokyo, meski saat itu sedang dalam kondisi pandemi Covid-19. Setibanya di rumah, polisi yang bertugas mengatakan bahwa ayahnya tewas dibunuh, dan polisi sedang menyelidiki siapa pembunuhnya. Kejutan berikutnya adalah kehadiran Kamio Takeshi, adik dari ayahnya yang selama ini jarang sekali pulang.Takeshi meniti karir sebagai seorang pesulap, dan dahulu meninggalkan Jepang untuk mencapai keinginannya menjadi pesulap tersohor. Karena itu dia jarang sekali pulang. Bersama Mayo, Takeshi menyelidiki kematian kakaknya dan berusaha menemukan pelakunya. Apalagi pihak kepolisian dengan sengaja tidak mau memberikan penjelasan terkait penyelidikan itu. Yang menjadi target adalah teman-teman SMP Mayo, yang juga mantan murid Kamio Eiichi.Ceritanya page turner, membaca setiap bab terasa singkat. Takeshi menyimpan banyak misteri dan rahasia, tapi caranya membuka misteri kematian kakaknya berbeda dengan Detektif Galileo di buku karya Keigi Higashino yang pernah saya baca. Bisa jadi karena penokohan Takeshi sebagai seorang pesulap, dia memanfaatkan banyak trik-trik untuk penyelidikannya.

Sebuah kota kecil di Jepang dilanda kelesuan karena sektor pariwisata yang mereka andalkan terpukul oleh pandemi. Meskipun demikian, warga kota sudah beradaptasi dan terbiasa dengan segala pembatasan yang ditetapkan. Di antara para warga, beberapa orang mempersiapkan reuni SMP yang akan dihadiri oleh alumnus dari berbagai penjuru Jepang. Tak disangka, sebelum reuni, Pak Guru Kamio Eiichi yang mereka hormati malah ditemukan terbunuh. Putrinya, Mayo bergegas pulang setelah menerima kabar duka tersebut. Di rumah yang telah menjadi TKP, adik Eiichi mendadak muncul. Kamio Takeshi adalah mantan pesulap di Amerika yang sekarang menjadi pemilik bar dan terkenal dengan gaya hidup yang seenaknya. Kemampuannya ia tunjukkan dengan mengambil informasi rahasia dari ponsel milik polisi yang sedang bertugas.Ternyata, Takeshi berniat untuk mencari tahu siapa pembunuh Eiichi sehingga Mayo terpaksa mendampinginya. Akankah Mayo dan Takeshi berhasil menemukan si pembunuh dan motifnya?** Jika dibandingkan dengan novel misteri lain, sebenarnya plot Black Showman termasuk standar. Secara pribadi, alasan pelaku mengingatkan pada novel lain Higashino sehingga saya kurang terkesan. Namun saya tidak menyesal telah membelinya. Kekuatan buku ini terletak pada latar dan penokohan. Bagi yang akrab dengan dunia manga, tokoh Takeshi pasti mengingatkan pembaca pada Kid Si Pencuri di Detektif Conan. Ini bukannya ketidaksengajaan, karena Takeshi sendiri menyebut nama Inspektur Megure (tokoh polisi dalam DC) saat bercanda. Gerakan tangan yang cepat serta trik psikologis untuk mengecoh lawan bicara membuat Takeshi sangat cocok sebagai penyelidik. Kepercayaan diri dan tingkah ngawurnya juga menjadi hiburan tersendiri meskipun sering membuat Mayo kesal dan bingung.Membaca latar cerita yang dekat dengan kondisi saat ini, awalnya saya merasakan suasana suram. Namun, Higashino berhasil menunjukkan kegigihan penduduk kota untuk bangkit kembali. Selain itu, seperti detektif Kaga di Newcomer, saat melakukan penyelidikan Takeshi juga mengulik masalah yang dimiliki masing-masing tokoh dan terkadang dia memberikan nasihat yang masuk akal. Optimisme ini membuat saya puas dengan endingnya.Saya beri nilai 3,7 üåü untuk novel ini.*Insert song Detective Conan* #BANYAKBACAAsianLit

buku pertama keigo-sensei yang gue baca.dan ya, gue cukup suka. dengan cara analisis si black showman yang mengingatkan gue dengan detektif-detektif lain yang gue idolakan ; Sherlock Holmes dan Conan Edogawa. juga dengan ide ceritanya yang sangat menarik.walaupun tokoh sentral di buku ini agak nyeleneh dan sedikit menyebalkan, tapi mungkin di situlah pesonanya.untuk plotnya, mengalir banget dan twistnya diletakkan di tempat yang tepat. ketika gue, sebagai pembaca sudah mulai memiliki kecurigaan dengan para tersangka yang disuguhkan, semuanya pun dibongkar.yang lumayan bikin mumet dari buku ini adalah cukup banyaknya tokoh yang terlibat di buku ini. harus benar-benar pay attention banget.

First j-lit & first Keigo Higashino sensei this year also (so far) my favoriteüéâWell what can I say... Higashino sensei is my auto-buy author.. Bukunya cukup tebal sekitar 500an halaman tapi page turner sekali (walau dibacanya sedikit-sedikit supaya tidak cepat selesaiüôà) Kasus pembunuhannya menarik walau bukan yang kompleks banget.. Setting nya relevan dengan masa kini dimana pandemi Covid 19 sedang merajarela, tak terkecuali di kota kecil tak bernamaAku suka dengan karakter paman Takeshi yang brilliant namun tengil dan acapkali sinis, semoga sensei berkenan menghadirkan karakter ini lagi di buku-buku mendatang, masih penasaran dengan latar belakang sang pamanü§≠

Dari ke-5 buku Keigo yg gue baca, buku ini dan Kesetiaan Mr. X a/ favorit gue sejauh ini dan 2 judul ini yg akan gue rekomendasikan buat yg mau coba baca buku2 Keigo.Banyak banget karakter yg terlibat di dalam kasus pembunuhan yg terjadi di buku ini. Sebab korban merupakan seorang guru SMP, maka tentunya tuduhannya jatuh kepada murid2nya sendiri. Makanya di antara 4 buku sebelumnya yg gue baca, buku ini punya alur paling rumit.Seinget gue, buku ini paling tebal di antara yg lainnya. Tapi yg namanya Keigo, kayanya memang "kerapihan gaya penulisan dan alur yg terstruktur" itu jadi special value dalam buku2nya, selalu hands down sama cara Keigo bercerita üëåDan, meskipun di sini engga ada tokoh detektif profesional yg memainkan peran utama dalam memecahkan kasus, akan tetapi gue suka kolaborasi peran detektif amatir antara paman dan keponakannya, yaitu Takeshi yg nyentrik dan Mayo yg selalu dibuat kesal karna tingkah laku pamannya yg konyol dan menyebalkan sepanjang cerita, lucu dan menghibur.

ini novel kesekian Keigo Higashino yang aku selesaikan.so far, buku ini menjadi least favourite-ku dari buku-buku beliau yang sudah aku baca.tapi tetap yaa, khas Keigo ngga pernah hilang.kali ini, kita akan mengulik kasus bersama dengan warga sipil, yang juga pesulap (eksentrik).aku selalu senang dengan kasus misteri, yang dipecahkan oleh warga sipil (yang juga bukan detektif partikelir). seru saja mengikutinya.
Okei buku ke 5 keigo sensei yang aku baca dan sukaaa üòç udah sesingkat ini aja reviewnya karena bingung mau nulis apa üòÖ

Waktu kemarin hampir selesai baca buku ini, udah punya feeling bakalan susah bikin reviewnya. Dan sekarang begitu bikin, bener donk bingung mau komentar apa.Baiklah, kita bikin kelebihannya dulu:- Ceritanya berlatar belakang di kota kecil yang terkena dampak covid 19--- kinda personal karena efek Covid yg relatable- Tokoh utamanya merupakan paman dan keponakan--- yes, lumayan unik karena bukan detektif- Ceritanya tentang mencari tahu siapa pembunuhnya--- bikin penasaran nebak2 siapa pembunuhnya- Dinamika Takeshi dan Mayo yg adorable banget---kayanya setiap keluarga punya orang ekstentrik di dalamnya, dan di cerita ini irang tersebut adalah Takeshi- Ceritanya cenderung santai, ga banyak dramaKekurangannya:- Ini buku tebel banget ---buat saya ga masalah karena lagi in the mood for thick book- Kebanyakan side story yang ga relate sama kasus pembunuhannya sendiri ---Again, buat saya ga masalah karena masih menarik buat dibaca- Karakternya lumayan banyak --- dulu udah pernah baca review yang bilang tokohnya banyak, jadi saya dari awal udah kasih tag di bagian penting tokoh-tokohnya biar ga bingungJadi kesimpulannya, apakah buku ini worth the hype? Buat saya sih yes üòÅüòÅ

Introduction yang bagus untuk mengenal Paman Takeshi sebagai tokoh utama yang baru. Buku ini menceritakan pembunuhan di kota tak bernama dan bagaimana keluarga korban (Takeshi dan Mayo) mencari siapa pelaku di balik pembunuhan Kamio Eiichi. Kalau buku sebelumnya hubungan dengan polisi aman damai, di buku ini para tokoh utama bermain api dengan polisi! Mereka saling bertarung untuk mengetahui siapa pembunuhnya. Hal ini dikarenakan Paman Takeshi tidak percaya dengan polisi üòÇ Paman Takeshi ini sangat nyentrik dan suka menantang polisi! Beliau digambarkan sebagai sosok yang pandai bersosialisasi, padahal sebenarnya *uhuk* licik. Kemudian Mayo yang merupakan putri Eiichi sekaligus keponakan Takeshi sangat polos sampai-sampai selalu ditipu dan diperas oleh pamannya sendiri üò≠üòÇ Dengan segala keahliannya dibidang sulap, Paman Takeshi sedikit demi sedikit membongkar mengapa kakaknya terbunuh. Setelah membaca buku ini saya baru sadar rasanya seperti menonton pertunjukan Paman Takeshi! Semoga ada kelanjutan tentang Paman Takeshi karena saya sangat menantikan cerita masa lalu dari Paman Takeshi dan apa yang dilakukannya setelah kasus ini.

The first time i read about homesexual in novel like this. Recently I read BL which gives me a viewpoint about gender, gay or les but it just stops in manga or fanfic and i still have intention to learn more about this matter. This is new theme of Keigo sensei wrote but i was surprised that Sensei already wrote it in 2000. I just think this novel is new-published. This novel tells story about people whose person inside and outside are different. It rose a question what defines man or woman by their nature or via biological characteristics? There is no absolute truth or answer about this question. There are people who sometimes acts as a woman while he is a man outside and vice versa. I see myself in this case sometimes, like i‚Äôm a girl and truly want to be a girl until now but sometimes I try to be gentlemen like a men, make some flirtings or try to be strong outside and inside. It never deep down think about it, maybe the environment, family situation which affect me to be me now. The novel said that there is no clear definition about man or woman, it‚Äôs like 2 direction line, it will be changed alternatively times by times from man to woman via situation. It somehow can make clear my actions. The plot twist of this novel didn‚Äôt make me feel touched in its ending. Because people in novel choose what they wanted to do and tried their best to protect what they treasured and I think that‚Äôs enough. In short the story itself didn‚Äôt satisfy me.

Hiromasa Hida has a secret. His daughter Kazumi is not really his daughter. He doesn't know whose daughter she is, but he is certain she is not his. His wife probably stole a baby from a hospital and brought her home. He found a newspaper article about the kidnapping of a baby after the passing of his wife. Probably unable to live with the knowledge of the kidnapping, his wife took her life. However, Hiromasa decided to keep silent and raise Kazumi by himself. Now Kazumi is knocking on the door of professional skying... and someone may have noticed her..."„Ç´„ÉÉ„Ç≥„Ç¶„ÅÆÂçµ„ÅØË™∞„ÅÆ„ÇÇ„ÅÆ" is a highly entertaining mystery novel from Keigo Higashino, a novel with a high pace, engaging characters and an interesting mystery that keeps the reader turning pages to its end. The writing is simple but it helps keeping the pace high and the characters interesting. Higashino has a habit of repeating some expressions (it is necessary to say every single time that the character is checking who is calling?) that are unnecessary, but in general the writing style fits the novel. And the mystery is fun enough and will keep the reader guessing. And there are more than a few suspects and storylines that things don't become boring.Sadly, Higashino can't keep the mystery to its very end, and the third act is a little bit disappointing. The twists and surprises are there, but they are not as interesting as Higashino may believe they are. The reader will enjoy it till its end, but may feel that the resolution is kind of a letdown after all that came before.7/10(Japanese Original Version)

4.5 stars

Have you ever wondered what a brain transplant can do to people? How would it change your life and your personality? This is the manga that you should read! This is about a guy who's been shot and been in vegetative state. The doctor then decides to do a brain transplant. Since then, Junichi can feel himself slowly change into someone else.This manga was so intense from the start. The gloomy atmosphere, the creepy artstyle matched with the certain scenes. I love the idea and the concept. We explore the idea of the brain (how it could change according to the circumstances). There are various characters that are suspicious (cause most of them have their own motives instead of helping Junichi)It is also hard to watch Junichi change into someone else (how he was so gentle and kind at the start but now he suddenly becomes violent). Very interesting. Can't wait to see what happens next.Highly recommend!!!

A shy worker gets shot in the head by a criminal while trying to save a kid and gets a brain transplant in order to live. Is he going to stay the same? What happens to his consciousness? A very good/well-written manga, with realistic characters and well-placed plot twists.

One of the best seinen manga that I have read in my life, the beginning is so sweet and I really feel in love with the characters and the developing of the main conflict. OMG! I cannot wait to follow with this reading.
I don't love the style, but it certainly is well-choreographed. The protagonist is shy, likable - someone I'm sure a lot of readers can identify with. Brilliant suspense, too!
Psych manga. Some amazing twist, well written.
Another rating: 8/10 (for whole series)

Series rating 1.5 stars.I remember watching the live action years ago and having a lot of fun with it. Bought the books almost immediately but always left them for later because I was so sure I'd enjoy them I decided to try other stories first.And well, maybe my expectations were too high, but I really didn't enjoy them. Especially the second book that felt too disjointed from the first one...

Higashino never ceases to amaze me with his way of narrating detective stories. One thing I like about his books is that, the detective stories themselves seem to be less attractive than the background he set and the way he narrates them. This one is the same. You know there is definitely something going on about the background, but you can't quite figure it out until he tells you at the end of the book. A short page turner that worth reading.

A bit slow paced, sometimes even languishing, but the logic at the end was impeccable and ties up the various deaths. Quite poignant near the end.

I'm surprised there is no such a book on goodreads. Probably books from Asia is not quite popular here. Actually I didn't read a lots of Asian fictions either. What I read the most are translated versions of "Western" books. But this summer I started to try some Asian fictions, and they are pretty good. Nemurerumori is of course one of them. And after this, I wanted to try more books written by Japanese writers, not only Keigo Higashino.Unfortunately, I can only read the translated version since I don't know any Japanese. But the translation is pretty good, much better than many "Western" books. The reason may be similarity between Chinese and Japanese.

** spoiler alert **
           This one was another sad one. I guess that's the trouble with Japanese crime novels. At least those by Higashino.Or maybe it's just the series. I actually came to know Kaga from a TV series first, then a follow up movie. Kaga was played by an actor i really like, Hiroshi Abe. His roles are sometimes sure of himself, sometimes not so sure, but always full of humanity.Maybe that is why he was a good choice for Kaga.But then again, I seem to find most Japanese crime/mystery novels are full of killers made by circumstances rather than preferences. Then again I could be wrong, it's been years since I read many of them.

Rating: 4 stars.I don't always like¬†Keigo Higashino's¬†books but Threads of Hope really is an enjoyable read. Better still, I happens to have visited¬†those few locations which are mentioned in the story as well.Outline of the story: a 50-something cafe owner was found stabbed to death in her kitchen, the police investigators learned the victim was well liked by her customers and there was seemingly no suspect who might hate her enough to do murder. Soon, the police noticed the victim's ex-husband and one of her frequent male customers were behaving strangely, were the two men hiding something?The male customer in question, was also having problem with his teenage daughter since his wife died due to illness, so what was his motive to get close to the caf√© owner?Meanwhile, one of the police investigators also received a phone call from a hotel owner who he had never heard of before, the older woman had shocking news for him. Most of the story is doing great, I really like the police investigation part of the story, the final explanation for the murder mystery is logical and well planned as well, I do like how the (view spoiler)[murder is committed mostly out of a very ill fated misunderstanding instead of malice, also as shocking is how the murdered victim is in fact the bio mother of the male customer's teenage daughter, out of a twist of fate (hide spoiler)], but the last 10 or so pages of the story, I don't like it so much, too much lecturing instead of story telling. *sighs*

Murder plot-wise, this novel is very simple; it disappointed me. So as a mystery novel, I wont recommend it to other people. But maybe Keigo Higashino‚Äôs strength is not there; I found the motive or hidden story of the case is usually deep and touching (as in ÁôΩÂ§úË°å which is my favorite among his works). I also didnt find his prose is exceptional or in any way beautiful. I read it in its original language, so it is not because of the translation. This is a first Japanese long novel I finished completely, in its original language! I am proud of myself lol..
